review.title: Using Description Logics for RDF Constraint Checking and Closed-World Recognition
review.abstract: RDF and Description Logics work in an open-world setting where absence of information is not information about absence. Nevertheless, Description Logic axioms can be interpreted in a closed-world setting and in this setting they can be used for both constraint checking and closed-world recognition against information sources. When the information sources are expressed in well-behaved RDF or RDFS (i.e., RDF graphs interpreted in the RDF or RDFS semantics) this constraint checking and closed-world recognition is simple to describe. Further this constraint checking can be implemented as SPARQL querying and thus effectively performed.

sections.text: We move from an RDF diagram to a slightly modified interpretation of the description logic, and from there perform a constraint check to determine whether a set of description logic axioms are satisfied in the interpretation or in a series of maximum extensions of the interpretation. We can also perform a recognition of the closed world by specifying the interpretation of the newly defined classes in the axioms, and these classes can even be defined recurrently. However, there is a missing part of the story. sections.heading: Complexity
sections.text: It is easy to see that checking axioms against an interpretation is a polynomial unless there is a new vocabulary in the axioms or recursive definitions; the formulas corresponding to the axioms are merely tested against the interpretation in a model way. If there are monotonous recursive definitions, constraints can be checked and closed world detection can be performed using techniques from the database, such as magic sets. For example, the extension of a recursively defined class can be calculated first without ignoring the recursive part. Violations of the recursive part can then be checked and objects can be iteratively removed from the class. These techniques cannot be used for non-monotonous recursive definitions, as the extension of one class or property could reduce another.

sections.heading: Implementation
sections.text: The work of Tao et al. (2010) shows that the standard constraints of the description logic can be partially implemented as SPARQL queries if no new vocabulary is used. Tao et al. (2010) worked in a general OWL environment where their approach is solid but not complete, but in an RDF environment the approach is both solid and complete, as there is only one model to take into account. This approach forms the basis of Stardog ICV (Clark & Parsia 2014). Indeed, Stardog ICV is an implementation of the approach described in this paper, which shows how the approach to constraints can be implemented here through a translation into SPARQL. The work here can also be thought of as a simpler definition of the underpinning of Stardog ICV.

sections.heading: Conclusion
sections.text: In fact, logic can be used for both the syntax and the semantics of constraint testing and closed-world detection in RDF, using an analogy of model testing, and much of the constraint testing and closed-world detection can be effectively translated into SPARQL queries by a translation. The main difference between closed-world detection and constraint testing is that the former either has no axioms or uses only axioms that define names that do not appear in the RDF diagram, whereas constraint testing uses axioms that correlate concepts that appear in the RDF diagram with descriptions. By restricting our information to RDF or RDFS, i.e. working in situations where there is a unique minimum model, we get a simpler formulation, simple implementation and good performance compared to previous work in this area, the WL can easily be expanded to this other subset of WL.
